channel.title: Networks
channel.description:
Networks
Lately, I have been building my home network. It now features: -3 Servers (1x Print, 2x Data) -A few hard disks -Fibre line (Only like 28MB to the internet)
I am thinking of reselling internet to people in my area. What would be the best way of doing this? Yes, I have checked with my ISP, I am allowed to resell.
Would it be easy to run a fibre line to a road (under ground) then have a switch port which feeds a Gigabit Ethernet cable into the customers houses? Or would it just be easier to set up a really powerful WiFi router on one of my servers which has a different access password per customer?

item.title: Networks
item.dc:creator: @Tico135 Tico
item.description:
@Tico135 wrote:

Good idea.

You could likely sell both. With wireless you could set up a router for a cheaper price, as it won’t be as strong of a signal. You could also sell wired by separating the ground all the way to that person’s house (about a centimeter or two wide) and use a stronger cable that prevents water damage to the cable (same thing as regular ISP’s would use) as there is simply no way an Ethernet cable would last too long, however I could be wrong. You could sell this service for more, as from the Ethernet cable they could set up their own router, etc.

Read full topic

item.title: Networks
item.dc:creator: @reVein reVein
item.description:
@reVein wrote:

^^ but wireless would be easier/faster to setup, “Would it be easy to run a fibre line to a road (under ground)”, so he wouldn’t need to break a fkn road…

btw runescapedude how are you going to limit their internet speeds then, afaik the speed you have gets shared between all the computers that are using it. if you had 5 customers, they’d be getting 5,6/mb speed and with 5 more customers the speed would cut down by half. ???

Read full topic

item.title: Networks
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

I think it’s best to use a line instead of wireless. With lines you get the max out of your connection.

Read full topic
